Also, the top level of the finding aid (above the dsc) changed to conform to current Rubenstein Library and NC EAD standards as laid out in the Inventory Style Guide and in the NCEAD Best Practice Guidelines. Within the dsc, dates for series were normalized. These changes were made by Michelle Belden.
Also, container TYPE and LABEL attribute values were standardized according to the Rubenstein Library EAD 2002 manual and the NCEAD eadlocal.ent by Ruth E. Bryan.
The tag list inside index was changed to indexentry by Ruth E. Bryan.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Lauchlin Bernard Currie papers 1931-1994 and undated

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, DukeUniversity

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferredto Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Lauchlin Bernard Currie Papers, Rare Book,Manuscript, and Special Collections Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The collection was received as a gift of the estate of Lauchlin Bernard Currie in 1998 and as a gift from another donor in 1998 and 1999.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Kirk White, Ann Langford, and Paula Jeannet Mangiafico
Encoded by Paula Jeannet Mangiafico and Lisa Stark
This finding aid is NCEAD compliant.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

chronitem.event: Studied at the London School of Economics
The Supply and Control of Money in theUnited States published.
Appointed Assistant on Economic Affairs by Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Acting Director of the Foreign Economic Administration
Loses U.S. Citizenship after being investigated by Senator Joseph McCarthy.
Advisor on economic issue to the government of Colombia.

bioghist.p: Lauchlin Bernard Currie (1902-1993) was an influential economist, advisor to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, 1939-1945, and to the government of Colombia, 1949-1993. He was involved with the Lend-Lease Program with China during WWII, and became acting director of the Foreign Economic Administration in 1943-44. This work resulted in his being a target during the McCarthy era and he lost his US citizenship in 1954. He settled in Colombia after 1954 and continued to serve as an advisor to the leaders of that country until his death in 1993.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Lauchlin Bernard Currie Papers, 1930-1997, serve to document the life, career, and theories of the economist. The collection chiefly consists of correspondence, published, materials, clippings, and subject files, and is primarily arranged chronologically and thematically. The bulk of the materials focus on Currie's analysis of macroeconomic policy during the New Deal, and growth, housing, and export policies for developing countries, especially Colombia. There is also material on China and Currie's mentor at Harvard Allyn Young

arrangement.p: Note: The Printed Materials Series of the Lauchlin Bernard Currie Papers has been processed and inventoried at an item level, but the Personal Papers Series beginning with Box 9 is unprocessed and requires careful handling, as many of the materials are fragile. The main collection (Acc. 1998-0039) is in the original order it was received with the exception of two accessions folded in after 1998 (1998-0349, 1999-0172). Small groups of materials received post-processing (2000-0251, 2001-0164, 2003-0208, and 2012-0051) are also listed. Folder groups headed only by a date span generally contain articles, reports, and correspondence on a wide variety of economic and socio-political subjects chiefly relating to plans for Colombia's economic development (headed by Currie) or to theories of development in poor nations. For more information on Currie's life, see the inventory files.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

Accession 2000-0251

scopecontent.p: This addition to the collection contains copies of correspondence and writings by Currie, as well as transcripts and other documents related to the investigation of Currie by the House Un-American Activities Committee. Most items are photocopies and were used by Professor Roger J. Sandilands for his article, Guilt by Association? Lauchlin Currie's Alleged Involvement with Washington Economists in Soviet Espionage, to be published in Fall 2000. A typescript of the article is also included.

did.unittitle: Accession (2003-0208)

scopecontent.p: The addition contains primarily correspondence between Currie and his biographer, Roger Sandilands, and related material about Currie's contributions to development economics (1992-1993). Includes comments on Currie's views and on the writings and positions of other economists.

scopecontent.p: Currie's subject files, chiefly related to Colombian economy. Materials in Spanish. File folders have numeric codes assigned; some numbers are missing.
